Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: The seminal cases Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003), establish that the controlling standard is always the child’s best interests, with an emphasis on stability, safety, and continuity of care.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states that in removal and custody determinations, the child’s best interests are the paramount concern and explains how those interests are evaluated, including the impact on the child’s stability and developmental needs and the interrelationship with the custodial parent’s well‑being. It does not use the exact trio of words “stability, safety, and continuity of care,” but its articulated best‑interests framework clearly emphasizes continuity of care (through the custodial parent), emotional and developmental needs, and overall welfare, consistent with the proposition that the controlling standard is always the child’s best interests with emphasis on those factors. Custody of Kali later builds on and reaffirms this best‑interests focus, so citing Yannas for that general standard is accurate.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’ … An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The seminal cases Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003), establish that the controlling standard is always the child’s best interests, with an emphasis on stability, safety, and continuity of care.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely reaffirms that the governing standard in custody determinations is the child’s best interests and explicitly cites Yannas for the proposition that the child’s best interests are always the paramount concern. It also emphasizes that stability and continuity of an adequate existing placement are central components of those best interests, warning against unnecessary disruption of satisfactory living arrangements. Thus, Custody of Kali directly supports the claimed proposition about best interests, with an emphasis on stability, safety, and continuity of care.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt:
“In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., … Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’)…
…If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement… Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The Court in Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), held that a judge must find both (a) a material change in circumstances since the prior judgment and (b) that modification serves the child’s best interest.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a generic modification standard case. The Court focuses on interpreting “upon cause shown” as requiring that removal be in the child’s best interests, and then applies a best-interests analysis; it does not state that a judge must first find a material change in circumstances and then that modification serves the child’s best interest. The only mention of “substantial change in circumstances” appears in a quoted ALI Principles passage in a footnote, not as a holding of the Court or as a required two-part test for modification generally or for removal orders specifically.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents … shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ … ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985) … Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court in Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981), confirmed that health and capacity of the parents are relevant to assessing changed circumstances.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses what factors a probate judge must weigh in modifying alimony and child support, focusing on income, earning capacity, assets, needs, and second-family expenses. It does not mention or analyze the health or physical/mental capacity of either parent as a relevant circumstance or factor in determining changed circumstances. Because health and capacity are not addressed at all, the case does not confirm that those are relevant to assessing changed circumstances.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … The needs of the children, the financial status of the support provider, and the station in life of the respective parties must all be considered.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Similarly, Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001), recognized that developments affecting a parent’s capacity to care for a child constitute sufficient grounds for modification.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The case does not say that developments affecting a parent’s capacity to care for a child are sufficient grounds for modification; it does the opposite here. The court holds that a modification of custody must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances and finds no such change, emphasizing that the mother’s work schedule and relocation, without more, do not warrant a custody change. Thus Rosenthal is authority for requiring a distinct, substantial change in circumstances beyond the move, not for treating such developments as sufficient grounds for modification.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28… We note, first, that a parent who works outside the home, even one with a ‘hectic’ schedule, may still be the appropriate primary caretaker and that, standing alone, such employment would not warrant a custody modification.”

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: The Court in Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006), emphasized that the safety of the child and ability of the custodial parent to provide care are essential components of the best‑interest analysis.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The opinion does conduct a best‑interests analysis under Yannas and discusses factors like schooling, housing, transitions, and the children’s relationship with each parent. However, it does not single out “safety of the child” or the “ability of the custodial parent to provide care” as distinct or emphasized components; instead, the focus is on the custodial parent’s real advantage and general quality‑of‑life factors. Thus, the specific proposition that Pizzino emphasizes those two elements as essential components of the best‑interest analysis overstates what the case actually says.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “In determining a child’s best interests, consideration must be given ‘to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.’ Yannas, 395 Mass. at 711.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998), and Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996), instruct that a child’s psychological and emotional welfare, including undue burden from caretaking roles, are relevant to custody determinations.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly emphasizes that the “best interests” analysis requires looking at the child’s psychological and emotional welfare, including the impact of disruptions, loss, and the need for a stable, predictable environment. The court discusses expert testimony about Hugo’s likely emotional reactions (bereavement, regression, mourning) and the importance of minimizing developmental deficits so he can function psychologically and socially, and it cites G.L. c. 210, § 3(c)(vii) regarding serious psychological harm from removal. That analysis squarely treats the child’s psychological and emotional welfare as relevant, and recognizes the burden of his caretaking/sibling relationship as one factor in that welfare. Combined with Custody of Vaughn (not quoted here), Hugo supports the proposition.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Rather, the judge appropriately considered the personal, educational, psychological, and other support available to each prospective parent to address Hugo’s needs… The judge explicitly considered the expert testimony regarding the trauma of separation for Hugo. He recognized that moving Hugo from his present foster home and its attendant network of supports ‘would cause yet another difficult transition’ for Hugo… We recognize that separating Hugo from his foster family will have negative consequences for him, although the experts disagree as to the long-term effects of those consequences.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998), and Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996), instruct that a child’s psychological and emotional welfare, including undue burden from caretaking roles, are relevant to custody determinations.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the custody inquiry around the child’s welfare and requires trial courts to make explicit findings on how domestic violence affects the child’s well‑being and the appropriateness of a custody award in light of those effects. The court emphasizes that witnessing family violence inflicts a distinct, serious psychological harm on children and that such harm must be considered in determining custody. That squarely supports the proposition that a child’s psychological and emotional welfare, including harms arising from family roles around violence, is relevant to custody determinations.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “It is well documented that witnessing domestic violence, as well as being one of its victims, has a profound impact on children. … There are significant reported psychological problems in children who witness domestic violence, especially during important developmental stages. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.proposition: Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (1986), and Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981), further affirm that the Court maintains continuing jurisdiction to modify custody where changed circumstances so warrant.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion is primarily about standards for permanent custody in a care and protection proceeding, not about modification of custody orders. However, the court explicitly notes that the order does not terminate all parental rights and that the parents "have available future opportunities to demonstrate their fitness and to regain custody," citing G. L. c. 119, § 26. This acknowledges the court’s ongoing authority to revisit custody based on changed circumstances, which is consistent with the proposition of continuing jurisdiction to modify custody.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.relevant_excerpt: We observe, however, that the judge’s order does not terminate all the rights of the parents regarding these two children. These parents have available future opportunities to demonstrate their fitness and to regain custody of their children. G. L. c. 119, § 26 (1984 ed.).

Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).proposition: Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (1986), and Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981), further affirm that the Court maintains continuing jurisdiction to modify custody where changed circumstances so warrant.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).support_reasoning: Felton v. Felton concerns modification of visitation provisions based on alleged religious harm to the children and applies the general ‘material change in circumstances’ standard from Schuler, but it does not discuss or affirm the Court’s *continuing jurisdiction* over custody or visitation orders. The opinion assumes jurisdiction without analyzing it and focuses instead on evidentiary sufficiency and best interests, so it is not authority for the specific proposition that the court maintains ongoing jurisdiction to modify custody upon changed circumstances. Any support for that proposition is at most implicit and incidental.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “3. We apply the words of Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981), a case seeking modification of alimony and child support provisions in a divorce judgment, to the present case, also demanding modification of a divorce judgment, although as to a different subject matter: ‘To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.’”
